intro: Vernonia paradoxa, commonly known as the blue mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of small, sky-blue to white flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. The plant produces small, three-lobed leaves that are typically gray-green in color, giving it a distinctive appearance. Vernonia paradoxa is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its ability to thrive in full sun and well-drained soil. It is often used in native plant gardens for its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
